name: Selenium
summary: Selenium is an essential trace mineral with antioxidant properties, important for thyroid function, immune health, and cellular protection.
description: Selenium is a trace element required for the synthesis of selenoproteins, which play critical roles in antioxidant defense, thyroid hormone metabolism, and immune regulation. Dietary selenium comes from plant and animal sources, with levels depending on soil selenium content. Adequate selenium intake helps protect cells from oxidative stress, supports normal thyroid function, and maintains a healthy immune response. Deficiency can impair immunity and thyroid activity, while excess supplementation can cause toxicity. Selenium has also been studied for its potential roles in cancer prevention, mood regulation, and cognitive health, though evidence is mixed.

metadata.natural_source: Brazil nuts, seafood, organ meats, cereals (soil-dependent)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for therapeutic indications)

off_label_uses: Adjunctive therapy in autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto’s disease)
contraindications: Pre-existing selenium toxicity or very high dietary selenium intake
monitoring_required: Serum selenium levels in long-term use
Signs of selenium toxicity (hair/nail changes, GI symptoms)

items: Supports thyroid hormone synthesis and metabolism
May modulate autoimmune thyroid disease progression

sections.text: Selenium is incorporated into selenoproteins, such as glutathione peroxidases and thioredoxin reductases, which protect against oxidative stress. It also plays a role in the conversion of thyroxine (T4) to the active thyroid hormone triiodothyronine (T3), supporting endocrine balance. Selenium influences immune regulation and may reduce inflammatory processes in autoimmune conditions.

adult.typical: 55 mcg/day (dietary reference intake); supplement doses often 100–200 mcg/day
adult.note: Upper intake level: 400 mcg/day to avoid toxicity.

sections.pediatric: Age-appropriate RDA; supplementation only under supervision.

sections.text: Nutritional benefits occur gradually with consistent intake; thyroid effects may be seen in weeks to months.

serious: Selenosis (toxicity) with high doses: neurological symptoms, GI upset, garlic-like breath odor

other: Avoid doses above 400 mcg/day due to risk of toxicity.
Excessive intake may increase risk of type 2 diabetes or skin cancer (conflicting evidence).
Soil selenium variability means dietary intake differs by region.

items: Serum selenium levels in high-dose or long-term use
Thyroid function tests if used adjunctively

sections.pregnancy: Safe in recommended dietary amounts; avoid high-dose supplementation
sections.lactation: Safe in dietary amounts; excess supplementation not recommended
sections.pediatrics: Use only within RDA; high-dose supplementation discouraged
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe; monitor for toxicity in high-dose use

sections.text: No tapering required; discontinue if toxicity suspected.

items: Brazil nuts are the richest natural source of selenium, though content varies widely.
Selenium deficiency is rare in developed countries but may occur with malabsorption or TPN without supplementation.
Some studies suggest benefit in Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, but evidence remains mixed.
